title: The State of Post-Quantum Cryptography (PQC) on the Web
summary: We analyze the world&rsquo;s most popular websites and most widely used web browsers to determine the current state of PQC adoption on the web.

title: Canary Exploit Tool for CVE-2025-30065 Apache Parquet Avro Vulnerability
summary: Investigating a schema parsing concern in the parquet-avro module of Apache Parquet Java.

title: 2025 Advanced Persistent Bot Report: Scraper Bots Deep-Dive
summary: How much do scraper bots affect your industry?

title: Prevent Web Scraping by Applying the Pyramid of Pain
summary: The Bots Pyramid of Pain: a framework for effective bot defense.

title: Analyzing the Global Increase in Vulnerability Scanning in 2024
summary: BotPoke comes to the foreground yet again.

title: Why Critical MongoDB Library Flaws Won't See Mass Exploitation
summary: Discover how to mitigate CVE-2024-53900 and CVE-2025-23061, which expose Node.js APIs to remote attacks.

title: Enterprises Should Consider Replacing Employees’ Home TP-Link Routers
summary: An examination of CVE trends from February 2025 scanning data.

title: The Dangers of DNS Hijacking
summary: How expired domains and improper DNS management can lead to severe security risks like MitM attacks, fraudulent TLS/SSL certifications, and more.

title: Black Friday Versus The Bots
summary: What can last year&rsquo;s Black Friday shopping trends teach us about expected attacker behavior during the 2024 holiday shopping season?

title: How to Identify and Stop Scrapers
summary: Fighting sophisticated scrapers requires advanced detection methods. Discover the techniques needed to identify and manage these hidden threats outlined in our investigation.

title: What Are Scrapers and Why Should You Care?
summary: Data miners and scraper bots are everywhere, feeding AI LLMs and more, and many of them are NOT harmless.

title: 2024 Bad Bots Review
summary: Learn the latest trends in bots and malicious automation so you can compare with attacks against your own organizations.

title: H1 2023 Bad Bots Review
summary: Bot traffic for the first half of 2023 was fairly typical, some rapid change in a few industries notwithstanding. Learn who got hit hard and who got off easy.

title: Bots Cheat to Win
summary: How automated fraudsters tried to ruin a restaurant&rsquo;s promotional contest.

title: Fake Account Creation Bots – Part 4
summary: The fourth and final part of a series investigating how automation is used to create fake accounts for fraud, disinformation, scams, and account takeover.

title: Bots Target Retailers for Black Friday Bargains
summary: Did automation targeting retail companies rise towards Black Friday 2022?

title: Fake Account Creation Bots – Part 3: 8 Ways to Identify Fake Bot Accounts
summary: Part three of a series investigating how automation is used to create fake accounts for fraud, disinformation, scams, and account takeover.

title: Fake Account Creation Bots – Part 2
summary: Part two of a series investigating how automation is used to create fake accounts for fraud, disinformation, scams, and account takeover.

title: Fake Account Creation Bots – Part 1
summary: Part one of a series investigating how automation is used to create fake accounts for fraud, disinformation, scams, and account takeover.

title: How a Sneaker Bot Earned $2M Profit from One Shoe Drop
summary: Explore a highly automated attack against a sneaker manufacturer and learn how resellers optimize their bots for success, and profit!

title: The Evolving CVE Landscape
summary: Plus, the 7 Weirdest CVEs (You won&rsquo;t believe number 6!)

title: 2023 DDoS Attack Trends
summary: We analyzed the last three years of DDoS data, and found attackers shifting to more complex approaches, and shifting up the stack.

title: Post-Breach Analysis: Sophistication and Visibility
summary: Analyzing a single attack in detail yields interesting findings about attacker sophistication, living off the land, and architectural risk.

title: Sensor Intel Series: Top CVEs in July 2022
summary: Learn which CVEs attackers scanned for the most in July 2022, and how it compares with the rest of the year.

title: BlackGuard Infostealer Malware: Dissecting the State of Exfiltrated Data
summary: Your data is at risk. Are you equipped to combat the risks posed by BlackGuard?

title: Introducing the Sensor Intel Series: Top CVEs Jan-Jun 2022
summary: Learn which CVEs attackers scanned for most in the first half of 2022.

title: What Are The Spring4Shell Vulnerabilities?
summary: Despite how they sound, Spring4Shell and the related vulnerabilities in the Spring Framework aren&rsquo;t exactly like Log4Shell. Learn how they work and what you can do.

title: 2022 Application Protection Report: In Expectation of Exfiltration
summary: Learn how the threat landscape evolved in 2021 so you can tune your defenses to suit.

title: FluBot’s Authors Employ Creative and Sophisticated Techniques to Achieve Their Goals in Version 5.0 and Beyond
summary: A deconstruction of FluBot 5.0&rsquo;s new communication protocol and other capabilities FluBot uses to hide, making it difficult for researchers and security solutions to detect.

title: Holiday Phishing Trends For 2021
summary: As Christmas quickly approaches, seasonal phishing trends once again show that attackers are taking advantage of increased online shopping. Fraudsters doubled their efforts in November attacking ecommerce giants such as Amazon. The real attacker focus, however, was cryptocurrency with fraudulent sites...

title: Explaining the Widespread log4j Vulnerability
summary: The log4j security vulnerability is one of the most widespread cybersecurity vulnerabilities in recent years. Here's a non-technical explanation of it.

title: How Global Cyberthreats Changed Over 2021
summary: Scans continue against remote logins like VNC, RDP, and SSH, as well as MySQL and Elasticsearch. And what&rsquo;s going on in Malaysia and Lithuania?

title: The 2021 TLS Telemetry Report
summary: Creating an encrypted HTTPS website depends on a lot more than simply throwing a digital certificate at it and hoping for the best. In fact, Transport Layer Security (TLS) and HTTPS misconfigurations are now so commonplace that in the 2021 OWASP Top 10, Cryptographic Failures now comes in second place....

title: Cyberattacks Targeting South Africa, January through June 2021
summary: South Africa&rsquo;s cyberattack landscape saw targeting of Scryba, PHP, and CVE-2017-9841 web vulnerabilities.

title: DDoS Against a Financial Service: Analysis of a Massive Attack
summary: A detailed look at an 840-Gbps DDoS attack on a financial services provider and a deeper dive into attacking nodes.

title: The State of the State of Application Exploits in Security Incidents
summary: The title of this report is not a typo. &ldquo;The State of the State of Application Exploits in Security Incidents&rdquo; is a meta-analysis of several prominent industry reports, each of which covers the state of application security.

title: Attacker Tricks for Taking Over Risk-Based Multifactor Authentication
summary: From spoofing device fingerprints to hijacking authenticated sessions, attackers use a range of techniques to bypass multifactor authentication.

title: Cyberattacks at Banks and Financial Services Organizations, and a Look at Open Banking
summary: A review of 2018-2020 cyberattacks at brokerages, investment funds, payment processors, and financial services organizations as well as API security incidents and open banking.

title: Cyberattacks at Banks and Financial Services Organizations
summary: A look at cybersecurity incidents at banks, credit unions, insurance companies, government-sponsored financial institutions, and stock exchanges.

title: DDoS Attack Trends for 2020
summary: Denial-of-service attacks are increasing and becoming more complex. We look at how attackers are attempting to bring down services around the world.

title: Cyberattacks Targeting Latin America, January through March 2021
summary: Latin America&rsquo;s cyberattack landscape saw continued focus on port 5900 and the targeting of common web vulnerabilities.

title: Email Compromise with Credential Stuffing Attack Tools
summary: How cybercriminals use credential stuffing attack tools OpenBullet and MailRanger to bypass CAPTCHA, compromise mailboxes, and reset passwords.

title: Collusion Fraud: The Art of Gaming the System with Complicity
summary: How platform business models are at an increased risk of fraud when two or more separate parties collude.

title: Credential Stuffing Tools and Techniques, Part 1
summary: We dig into the credential stuffing attack tool OpenBullet and look at configuring combolists, proxies, parse tokens, and check blocks for launching attacks.

title: How The IcedID Banking Trojan Exploits The Pandemic
summary: TA551 (AKA Shathak) deploys the IcedID banking trojan using COVID-19 in Microsoft Word documents containing a malicious macro that drops an installer.

title: Threats, Vulnerabilities, Exploits and Their Relationship to Risk
summary: The tale of The Three Little Pigs can teach us more than you think about cybersecurity risk.

title: Cyberthreats Targeting India, October through December 2020
summary: India&rsquo;s attack landscape saw focus on Port 5900 and the highest number of scans from the UK.

title: 2021 Credential Stuffing Report
summary: Credential stuffing is a multifaceted and enduring risk to organizations of all types and sizes. This report is a comprehensive examination of the entire life cycle of stolen credentials&mdash;from their theft, to their resale, and their repeated use in credential stuffing attacks.

title: Red Team Tools Reveal Gaps in Vulnerability Management Practice
summary: FireEye tools show attackers aren&rsquo;t worried about your defenses.

title: Can Bots Manipulate Data and Change Facts to Fiction?
summary: Data manipulation is a real threat to data-driven approaches at enterprises. We tested one of our own assets to see the possibilities.

title: IoT Vulnerability Assessment of the Irish IP Address Space
summary: Vulnerability assessment of IoT devices in Ireland detailing the biggest threats, most at-risk and highly exposed devices.

title: 2020 Phishing and Fraud Report
summary: In our 2020 edition of the Phishing and Fraud Report, we focus on how cybercriminals build and host phishing sites, the tactics they use to avoid detection, and how they&rsquo;ve capitalized this year on the COVID-19 pandemic.

title: How Cyber Attacks Changed During the Pandemic
summary: Cybersecurity attacks surged during the pandemic, with large jumps in DDoS and password login attacks against online retailers and APIs.

title: JWT: A How Not to Guide
summary: JWT brings performance to identity assertion and is being widely adopted, but it&rsquo;s also garnering the attention of cybercriminals.

title: The Rising IoT Threat to the Agriculture Industry and the Global Food Supply
summary: Precision agriculture leveraging IoT and API technology is both a great boon and a huge cybersecurity risk.

title: API Authentication Incidents: 2020 Application Protection Report, Volume 2
summary: Broken API authentication is leading to avoidable security incidents and unusual impacts. Learn what you can do to control the risk.

title: How Credential Stuffing Bots Bypass Defenses
summary: Website logins are under constant assault, with attackers quickly modifying their bots to evade simplistic defenses.

title: How I Designed an Open Source HTTPS Checker
summary: F5 Labs summer intern describes her experiences building a Python-based HTTPS scanning library for security research and release as an open source tool.

title: 2020 Application Protection Report, Volume 1: APIs, Architecture, and Making Sense of the Moment
summary: Securing APIs demands a new approach. See what we can learn from API incidents and where to begin.

title: How Credential Stuffing Is Evolving
summary: Cred stuffing isn't going away. Shape's Jarrod Overson writes for InformationSecurityBuzz, examining the ROI of cred stuffing for attackers, and the evolution to &quot;imitation attacks&quot;.

title: Qbot Banking Trojan Still Up to Its Old Tricks
summary: The Qbot banking trojan is back, targeting American banks with dedicated campaigns followed by stealth and evasion techniques.

title: 2019 Application Protection Report
summary: This is the most in-depth version of the 2019 Application Protection Report. It contains research and data from all of the 2019 episodes, updated with 2019 breach trends that paint a clearer picture of where application threats are heading. Cancel some afternoon meetings and take a deep dive with us!...

title: Top Attacks Against Financial Services Organizations 2017–2019
summary: Attackers are targeting financial services organizations with brute force, credential stuffing, and DoS attacks. See how you can mitigate the risks.

title: Mirai “COVID” Variant Disregards Stay-at-Home Orders
summary: New Mirai variant references the COVID-19 pandemic with a filename change and two targets: Huawei routers and TeamSpeak.

title: Privacy and Surveillance: How Generation Z and Millennials See the Internet of Things
summary: Over 700 survey respondents from different generations shared their views about the IoT and the tradeoffs between privacy and convenience.

title: Cyberthreats Targeting Canada, Winter 2019
summary: The Canadian threat landscape was characterized by a large amount of attack traffic from in-county systems, which can be the most difficult to filter.

title: Cyberthreats Targeting Australia, Winter 2019
summary: The Australian threat landscape closely mirrored the threats we observed in Asia, with an added focus on NetBIOS port 139.

title: Cyberthreats Targeting the United States, Winter 2019
summary: The attack landscape targeting US systems was characterized by a large amount of traffic directed at web applications and web app databases.

title: Cyber Threats Targeting Russia, Winter 2019
summary: The Russian threat landscape is unique from other regions of the world in that it had the most unique attacking IP addresses.

title: Cyber Threats Targeting Middle East, Winter 2019
summary: Attackers used two top ASNs to broadly distribute IP addresses in an attempt to camouflage attack traffic targeting Middle Eastern systems.

title: Cyber Threats Targeting Asia, Winter 2019
summary: Asian systems saw a large amount of SMB attack traffic during this time period, mainly driven from in-region IP addresses.

title: New Perl Botnet (Tuyul) Found with Possible Indonesian Attribution
summary: Tuyul bot targets vulnerable PHPUnit systems to install an Internet Relay Chat (IRC) bot.

title: 2019 TLS Telemetry Report Summary
summary: The Summary of the 2019 F5 Labs TLS Telemetry Report expands the scope of our research to bring deeper insights into encryption on the web, including ciphers, SSL/TLS versions, and digital certificates.

title: Are Gen Z-ers More Security Savvy Online than Millennials?
summary: An F5 Labs survey of Gen Z-ers revealed they are not much more security savvy online than Millennials.

title: Top Attacks Against Service Providers 2017-2019
summary: Three years of data shows DDoS attacks against service providers are growing while brute force and other authentication attacks are slowly waning.

title: Vulnerabilities, Exploits, and Malware Driving Attack Campaigns in December 2019
summary: Threat campaign activity in December 2019 doubled from the previous month.

title: Black Friday, Cyber Monday and the Seasonal E-Commerce Onslaught
summary: The holiday shopping season is a bonanza for both shoppers and attackers. F5 Labs' David Warburton writes for ITProPortal, discussing the most commonly seen seasonal threats and how annual trends are shifting.

title: Gafgyt Targeting Huawei and Asus Routers and Killing Off Rival IoT Botnets
summary: IoT botnet Gafgyt targets popular routers through RCE vulnerabilities, and even removes competing malware.

title: Vulnerabilities, Exploits, and Malware Driving Attack Campaigns in November 2019
summary: New campaign activity for remote code execution (RCE) vulnerabilities disclosed this year picked up in the month of November.

title: Regional Threat Perspectives, Fall 2019: Russia
summary: The same countries that attacked the rest of the world also attacked systems in Russia, but from different networks and IP addresses.

title: Regional Threat Perspectives, Fall 2019: Asia
summary: Attackers targeted applications and conducted credential stuffing attacks against systems in Asia during the fall of 2019.

title: Echobot Malware Now up to 71 Exploits, Targeting SCADA
summary: A Mirai variant named Echobot appeared mid-2019. Echobot has been seen expanding its arsenal to 71 exploits, targeting SCADA systems and IoT devices.

title: Regional Threat Perspectives, Fall 2019: Europe
summary: Europe saw more in-region attack traffic&mdash;the hardest kind to filter out&mdash;than any of the 8 regions of the world we analyzed.

title: Regional Threat Perspectives, Fall 2019: Australia
summary: Attackers probed Australian applications for vulnerabilities on the most commonly used ports, and credential stuffing attacks were prevalent.

title: DanaBot’s New Tactics and Targets Arrive in Time for Peak Phishing and Fraud Season
summary: DanaBot makes a strong resurgence at the end of 2019, using new tactics and techniques and expanding beyond its traditional banking targets.

title: Regional Threat Perspectives, Fall 2019: Latin America
summary: Latin American systems received more attacks from IP addresses within the region that coincidentally did not attack anywhere else in the world.

title: Regional Threat Perspectives, Fall 2019: Canada
summary: The U.S. and Canada have 95% of top source traffic countries in common.

title: Vulnerabilities, Exploits, and Malware Driving Attack Campaigns in October 2019
summary: Vulnerable web servers are the top target for threat actors, who continue to exploit known vulnerabilities with the goal of running commands remotely.

title: Regional Threat Perspectives, Fall 2019: United States
summary: U.S. systems were heavily targeted by IP addresses in Russia, Moldova, and France that launched credential stuffing attacks on VNC port 5900 beginning in June 2019.

title: Regional Threat Perspectives, Fall 2019: Middle East
summary: IP addresses assigned in Russia launched significantly more attacks against Middle East systems than any other regions of the world.

title: Application Protection Research Series—Summary 2nd Edition
summary: The short, concentrated brief on the 2019 application threat landscape, and what you can do to protect your apps.

title: Vulnerabilities, Exploits, and Malware Driving Attack Campaigns in September 2019
summary: Threat actors shift focus away from cryptominers and back to remote code execution&mdash;this month with a new zero-day exploits.

title: Three Ways to Hack the U.S. Election
summary: There are three primary avenues to hack a U.S. election: voter registration, voting machines, and the voters themselves. We&rsquo;ll dig into each and see which offers the most bang for the buck.

title: 2019 Application Protection Report Podcast Series
summary: In this companion podcast, the 2019 F5 Labs Application Protection Report researchers examine how both apps and threats are changing, and what security practitioners can do to stay ahead of these changes.

title: Vulnerabilities, Exploits, and Malware Driving Attack Campaigns in August 2019
summary: August 2019 was slowest month on record F5 researchers have seen in new threat activity. But while active exploitation slowed, new reconnaissance campaigns grew.

title: Tricky Trickbot Runs Campaigns Without Redirection
summary: Known for redirection attacks, recent Trickbot banking trojan campaigns use server-side injection and target fewer victims.

title: How To Survive the Rash of Ransomware
summary: Ransomware is ramping up, especially in the public sector. The key to stopping these attacks is to focus on the ransomware attack vectors.

title: De-icing IcedID: Decompression and Decryption Methods Explained in an IcedID Attack
summary: We detail the steps for decrypting and decompressing IcedID webinject files, enabling researchers to analyze IcedID samples and pull out target and web injection files.

title: Application Protection Report 2019, Episode 5: API Breaches and the Visibility Problem
summary: API use has grown tremendously, but security is lagging, creating easy targets for attackers.

title: Kazakhstan Attempts to MITM Its Citizens
summary: Kazakhstan is now asking its citizens to install digital certificates so that it can decrypt all online communications. Their methods, however, may leave the population vulnerable to cyber attacks for many years to come.

title: Vulnerabilities, Exploits, and Malware Driving Attack Campaigns in June 2019
summary: Similar to April and May, threat actors in June continued targeting the deserialization vulnerabilities found in Oracle WebLogic to mine cryptocurrency.

title: 2018 Application Protection Report Podcast Series
summary: In this companion podcast, the researchers who created the F5 Labs Application Protection Report discuss their findings, and share the details and backstories that helped shape the final report.

title: The Hunt for IoT: The Opportunity and Impact of Hacked IoT
summary: We&rsquo;re still thinking of Internet of Things devices as low risk when reality tells us exactly the opposite.

title: New Golang Malware is Spreading via Multiple Exploits to Mine Monero
summary: A newcomer to the malware scene, Golang-based malware has been seen installing cryptominers specifically targeting Moreno cryptocurrency.

title: Vulnerabilities, Exploits, and Malware Driving Attack Campaigns in May 2019
summary: Similar to April, threat actors in May continued targeting the deserialization vulnerabilities found in Oracle WebLogic to mine cryptocurrency.

title: Application Threat Report 2019, Episode 4: Access Attack Trends in 2018
summary: Access attacks that circumvent user authentication, such as phishing or credential stuffing, are the types that most commonly lead to a breach.

title: How I Hacked the Microsoft Outlook Android App and Found CVE-2019-1105
summary: It looked like a simple XSS in the Outlook Android app, but the app developers couldn&rsquo;t reproduce it so they didn&rsquo;t fix it. Then things got interesting. Here&rsquo;s the story of how I discovered CVE-2019-1105.

title: Gootkit Italian Campaign Overview
summary: The Gootkit banking trojan is still active and protecting itself in Italy using a dedicated redirection defense.

title: Application Protection Report 2019, Episode 3: Web Injection Attacks Get Meaner
summary: Web injection represents an even greater risk than it did previously, thanks to the growth of third-party content and increasingly complex attack surfaces.

title: Vulnerabilities, Exploits, and Malware Driving Attack Campaigns in April 2019
summary: In April, threat actors focused on targeting vulnerabilities that had the highest impact: this month it was a recently released deserialization vulnerability in Oracle WebLogic Server.

title: Regional Threat Perspectives: United States
summary: Attackers using IP addresses in Vietnam, China, and Russia focused on attacking applications over Samba, SSH, and HTTP.

title: Gozi Banking Trojan Pivots Towards Italian Banks in February and March
summary: Gozi authors, who targeted banks in Canada, France, and the US in January 2019, shifted their targets to Italian banks in February 2019.

title: Denial of Service Vulnerabilities Discovered in HTTP/2
summary: SETTINGS frame abuse and Slow POST attacks in HTTP/2 can lead to CPU and memory exhaustion.

title: Panda Malware: It’s Not Just About Cryptocurrencies Anymore
summary: Panda malware is back with a March 2019 campaign that targets U.S. companies, and moves from cryptocurrencies to targeting web giants.

title: Regional Threat Perspectives: Australia
summary: Attackers using IP addresses in China, the United States, and the Netherlands focus on attacking applications over SSH, SMB and HTTP.

title: Ramnit Returns to its Banking Roots, Just in Time for Italian Tax Season
summary: Ramnit&rsquo;s latest configuration targets Europe leading up to tax season, focusing on Italian banks and international online advertisers.

title: Regional Threat Perspectives: Europe
summary: Attackers are using IP addresses in the Netherlands, United States, and China to target systems in Europe over SIP, Microsoft SMB, and SSH.

title: Vulnerabilities, Exploits, and Malware Driving Attack Campaigns in March 2019
summary: In March, threat actors focused on targeting vulnerabilities released in the last few months. WordPress Easy SMTP Plugin Authentication Bypass vulnerability attacks had the most impact during that time frame.

title: Application Protection Report 2019, Episode 2: 2018 Breach Trends
summary: Analysis of public breach reports showed a relationship between business models and breach vectors, with injection and phishing the leading causes.

title: Why Attacks on Cryptocurrency Exchanges Show No Signs of Slowing Down
summary: F5 Labs' Ray Pompon writes for Finance Derivative, discussing why hackers will continue targeting cryptocurrency exchanges.

title: “CryptoSink” Campaign Deploys a New Miner Malware
summary: Attackers continue to exploit old vulnerabilities, use new methods to kill competing crypto-miners, and survive removal by administrators.

title: Vulnerabilities, Exploits, and Malware Driving Attack Campaigns in February 2019
summary: Continuing the trend from January, threat actor activity in February focused heavily on exploiting a ThinkPHP remote code execution vulnerability.

title: Vulnerabilities, Exploits, and Malware Driving Attack Campaigns in January 2019
summary: January threat actor activity focused heavily on exploiting a ThinkPHP remote code execution vulnerability and infecting vulnerable Oracle WebLogic systems with a Mirai variant.

title: Gozi Adds Evasion Techniques to its Growing Bag of Tricks
summary: Gozi &ldquo;banking&rdquo; trojan continues to shift its targets beyond banking as it employs client-side and server-side evasion techniques via time-tested web injection.

title: Fighting Back Against Phishing and Fraud—Part 1
summary: Using existing protocols and tools to begin building a robust phishing and fraud mitigation strategy.

title: Spaceballs Security: The Top Attacked Usernames and Passwords
summary: Expect a breach If you have basic, vendor default SSH credentials active on any system.

title: Threat Actors Rapidly Adopt New ThinkPHP RCE Exploit to Spread IoT Malware and Deploy Remote Shells
summary: Threat actors wasted no time jumping on this new exploit to launch new campaigns for reconnaissance, uploading back doors, and deploying variants of the Mirai botnet.

title: DanaBot November Campaigns Target European Banks and Email Providers
summary: First detected in May 2018, DanaBot is a fraud trojan that has since shifted its targets from banks in Australia to banks in Europe, as well as global email providers such as Google, Microsoft and Yahoo for the holiday phishing season.

title: Reviewing Recent API Security Incidents
summary: Application programming interfaces (APIs) are a growing attack surface, offering predators unprecedented access to large data stores. As serverless, mobile, and online platforms grow, API attacks will surely rise.

title: Will Losses from Cryptocurrency Exchange Hacks Hit a Billion Dollars In 2018?
summary: Cryptocurrency exchanges and their supporting application systems are being attacked at an unprecedented level. As the value of cryptocurrency has climbed, so has the incentive to steal.

title: Abusing Googlebot Services to Deliver Crypto-Mining Malware
summary: Seventeen years after the opportunity for abuse was made public, attackers are finding new ways to make use of this unpatched web crawler service.

title: Ready or Not, Cyberwarfare Is Here
summary: By targeting critical infrastructure, cyberwarfare attackers can plunge a nation into chaos without ever firing a single shot.

title: Organizations Seek Help Fighting App-Focused DDoS Attacks Even as Total DDoS Attack Rates Stay Flat
summary: While DDoS attack rates hold, tensions rise for organizations trying to mitigate app-targeted attack that can be easily launched by script kiddies.

title: Trickbot Gets Trickier by Adding an Encryption Layer
summary: Trickbot authors gain precious time to defraud unsuspecting victims by adding an encryption layer that slows down the malware investigation process.

title: Apache Struts 2 Vulnerability (CVE-2018-11776) Exploited in CroniX Crypto-Mining Campaign
summary: Attackers are exploiting new vulnerabilities almost as quickly as they're being discovered.

title: Rental Scams Are Pervasive, Even Years After the Housing Recession
summary: Rental scams are getting more sophisticated and are making it harder for legitimate landlords and renters to find each other.

title: Tackling Gootkit's Traps
summary: Gootkit malware uses misleading code to hinder manual research and automated analysis.

title: New Jenkins Campaign Hides Malware, Kills Competing Crypto-Miners
summary: Threat actors continue to find creative yet relatively unsophisticated ways to launch new campaigns to reap profits from crypto-mining operations.

title: Snooping on Tor from Your Load Balancer
summary: An F5 Labs researcher snoops on Tor exit node traffic from a load balancer. What he finds will shock you. SHOCK YOU.

title: BackSwap Defrauds Online Banking Customers Using Hidden Input Fields
summary: BackSwap demonstrates unique behavior in its manipulation of user input fields and its handling of International Bank Account Numbers (IBANs).

title: New Struts 2 Campaign Compiles Its Own C# Downloader, Leverages a User Profile Page as Its C&C Server
summary: Attackers continue to find new and creative ways to carry out malicious crypto-mining operations, employing multiple exploits in a single campaign.

title: New Campaign Targeting Apache Struts 2, WebLogic Deploys Malware Using VBScript
summary: With the vast availability of new exploits and the competition for victims&rsquo; resources, the multi-exploit trend continues to be popular among attackers.

title: Russian Attacks Against Singapore Spike During Trump-Kim Summit
summary: Singapore saw a sharp rise in attacks targeting a variety of ports, from SIP clear-text (5060), Telnet, SQL, and host-to-host ports to those used for remote router management and proxy servers and caching.

title: Drupalgeddon 2 Highlights the Need for AppSecOps
summary: If you aren&rsquo;t aware of Drupalgeddon 2, then you&rsquo;ve either been living off the grid or don&rsquo;t use the popular content management system (CMS).

title: Panda Malware Broadens Targets to Cryptocurrency Exchanges and Social Media
summary: Panda malware is back in full force with three currently active campaigns that extend its targets beyond banking to new industries and organizations worldwide.

title: Russia Attacks Global Network Infrastructure Through Vulnerabilities That Extend Far Beyond Their Targets
summary: US-CERT TL18-106A alert underscores how insecure Internet systems really are and that ignoring the problem only increases the collateral damage.

title: The 2017 TLS Telemetry Report
summary: Privacy today isn&rsquo;t just about staying away from prying eyes. The very act of communicating across the Internet with open, non-confidential protocols invites exposure to multiple threat types.

title: Windows IIS 6.0 CVE-2017-7269 is Targeted Again to Mine Electroneum
summary: Attacks are back to targeting a Windows IIS vulnerability first disclosed a year ago to mine Electroneum.

title: Know the Risks to Your Critical Apps and Defend Against Them
summary: Critical apps are the ones that must never go down or be hacked. They are also the hardest to defend because they are often massive, ancient, and touch everything.

title: Avoid Becoming a Crypto-Mining Bot: Where to Look for Mining Malware and How to Respond
summary: People are mining coins all over the place-all it costs is money for the power bill. So, of course, clever people are figuring out how to use other people&rsquo;s power to mine cryptocurrency.

title: Old Dog, New Targets: Switching to Windows to Mine Electroneum
summary: Apache Struts 2 Jakarta Multipart Parser RCE crypto-mining campaign is now targeting Windows, not just Linux systems.

title: When Information Security is a Matter of Public Safety
summary: Seven steps for improving the security of critical infrastructure systems&mdash;and protecting the public from unnecessary risk.

title: The Hunt for IoT: The Growth and Evolution of Thingbots Ensures Chaos
summary: IoT attacks show no signs of decreasing while infected IoT devices go un-remediated, and discovery of new thingbots is at a decade-long high.

title: Threat Modeling the Internet of Things: Modeling Reaper
summary: Reaper is just one more blinking light in the faces of the InfoSec community reminding us that we need to get ahead of IOT madness.

title: rTorrent Vulnerability Leveraged in Campaign Spoofing RIAA and NYU User-Agents?
summary: The same rTorrent XML-RPC function configuration error that was targeted to mine Monero in February was also targeted in January in a campaign apparently spoofing user-agents for RIAA and NYU.

title: Exploited Memcached Servers Lead to Record-Setting 1.3Tbps DDoS Attack
summary: Memcached is just one of many application infrastructure systems that could launch the same types of attacks if they were also misconfigured.

title: rTorrent Client Exploited In The Wild To Deploy Monero Crypto-Miner
summary: A previously undisclosed misconfiguration vulnerability in the rTorrent client is being exploited in the wild to mine Monero.

title: XMRig Miner Now Targeting Oracle WebLogic and Jenkins Servers to Mine Monero
summary: The same drop zone server used last week to mine Monero on compromised Jenkins automation servers is now being used in a new Monero mining campaign targeting Oracle Web Logic servers.

title: Beware of Attackers Stealing Your Computing Power for their Cryptomining Operations
summary: As the black-market price for stolen data declines, attackers turn to cryptojacking schemes to maximize their profits&mdash;all at your expense.

title: The Email that Could Steal Your Life Savings and Leave You Homeless
summary: Real estate scams are big business for attackers. Be on the lookout for this one, which can leave home buyers destitute if not caught in time.

title: Thingbots and Reapers and Cryptominers—Oh, My! F5 Labs’ First Year in Review
summary: F5 Labs covered a multitude of threats, vulnerabilities, botnets, attackers, and attacks in 2017. Here are just some of the highlights you might have missed.

title: Ramnit Goes on a Holiday Shopping Spree, Targeting Retailers and Banks
summary: Ramnit&rsquo;s latest twist includes targeting the most widely used web services during the holidays: online retailers, entertainment, banking, food delivery, and shipping sites.

title: A Spectre of Meltdowns Could be in Store for 2018, Including Fileless Malware Attacks and More Costly Bots

Setting up Your Own Certificate Authority for Development: Why and How., (Wed, Jul 9th)
summary: There are several reasons why one would set up an internal certificate authority. Some are configured to support strong authentication schemes, some for additional flexibility and convenience. I am going to cover the second part. In particular, it can be helpful for developers to have an internal certificate authority to issue certificates for development purposes. Websites used for development and internal testing are usually only used by a few individuals and are generally only accessible via internal networks or VPNs. Often, these sites do not even use TLS. But there are a few reasons why you should consider running TLS on all sites, including internal development sites:

title: ISC Stormcast For Tuesday, July 8th, 2025 https://isc.sans.edu/podcastdetail/9516, (Tue, Jul 8th)
What's My (File)Name?, (Mon, Jul 7th)
summary: Modern malware implements a lot of anti-debugging and anti-analysis features. Today, when a malware is spread in the wild, there are chances that it will be automatically sent into a automatic analysis pipe, and a sandbox. To analyze a sample in a sandbox, it must be "copied" into the sandbox and executed. This can happen manually or automatically. When people start the analysis of a suspicious file, they usually call it "sample.exe", "malware.exe" or "suspicious.exe". It&&#x23;x26;&#x23;39;s not always a good idea because it&&#x23;x26;&#x23;39;s can be detected by the malware and make it aware that "I&&#x23;x26;&#x23;39;m being analyzed".
